ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: About 4 hours a week of reading/assignments
3 hours.
8 hours
5-6hrs
16 hours to 30 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This course was very informative. There were some role-play activities that were not very instructive but it was an informative course overall.
The course was interesting, but the format of the discussions could be improved. The size of the class seemed too large.

I think this class was a great blend between health policy and economics. Sometimes it was interesting having a class that was half MPH and half senior econ majors, but most times it provided for good discussions. I liked the set-up of the course in terms of covering a new addiction/theme in each class.
The material taught in this course is really interesting and that's the highlight of the course.

Extremely interesting and engaging topic, with lots of material from the instructor and lots of opportunities to read, think, write and get feedback. The class was pretty large and so it took time for the group to gel, and the discussion sessions weren't always as lively as they might have been. Bringing together MPH policy people with undergraduate econ students wasn't that great a success but wasn't a complete failure either.The assignments had about the right level of informality and formality of approach.

This class had the potential to be so much more than it was. Too much time was spent on understanding the problem, rather than discussing the current and emerging solutions that have been tried to combat these issues of addiction, etc.

The dynamic between the undergrads and graduate students was challenging and I think the discussion might have benefited from greater involvement from the professor to bridge that gap.I would argue the material on behavioral economics was the most valuable piece of the course and would have liked to have seen more emphasis put on this and other economic frameworks. While structuring around the specific issues is logical, I think a little less of the specifics of the addictions and a little more on the economics and policies surrounding them would have been valuable.
Strength: Weekly assignments.Weakness: Lots of info on power points.
I liked it although I thought the forced participation was too much.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Jody Sindelar  Dr. Sindelar is a nice woman but she had some difficulty explaining concepts or responding to student questions.

Instructor: Jody Sindelar  Prof. Sindelar was incredibly accommodating in making sure that everyone in the class was keeping up with the course material. She was very friendly and made a great effort to try and get to know everyone in the class.

Instructor: Jody Sindelar  Dr. Sindelar is a great professor. I think learning more specifics about what work she does/has been involved with in the past for a class would be very interesting, just to get an idea of real-world applications of the topics covered in class. Also, stressing the importance of class participation in this type of seminar class is fine at the beginning of the semester, but I think too much effort was put on trying to get everyone to constantly participate or implement a system of incentives, etc. I think students would have just participated naturally, knowing that it was an important part of the class. Getting her feedback on our final paper topic ideas was extremely helpful, as were post-presentation comments.
Instructor: Jody Sindelar  Jody is an interesting professor. She brings forth the concept of behavioral economics into public health, which is really intriguing.

Instructor: Jody Sindelar  I particularly liked the enthusiasm of the instructor for the course topic and material, and her focus on the economic principles underlying the course. She and the TA gave good feedback on assignments.

Instructor: Jody Sindelar  While the instructor was extremely supportive and accessible, I think it would have been beneficial to receive a little more specific feedback, especially on the final presentations.
Instructor: Jody Sindelar  Great. Very supportive.
Instructor: Jody Sindelar  sometimes frazzled, but overall, good teacher. knowledgeable.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Did not have much interaction with Nick, other than a few emails. He was responsive and knowledgeable.

Nick provided helpful comments on the graded homeworks. I found his ideas about our final paper topic ideas to be useful. He was also very prompt about responding to email questions, which I appreciated.
Didn't have much to do directly with the TA, but the feedback on assignments was all helpful.
The TA was helpful in providing feedback on the final paper and was knowledgeable concerning the material, specifically the economic models.
Fine. Good advice.
helpful.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If you want to learn about addiction and economics, this is a fascinating course.
This course was a nice balance to my other courses. It was interesting to learn about how to integrate an economics perspective into health policy in the context of addiction.

I probably would recommend this course to another student because it is an interesting niche of health policy/economics that has a lot of need, but that you don't necessarily hear too much about (except maybe the addiction of obesity). Although several of the graded homeworks seemed a bit repetitive and on the tedious side, the readings for the most part were very applicable and the final project served as a cumulative way to apply themes from the course to a specific addiction.
It's a good class to take if you're interested in behavioral aspects of policy. (which if you want to be a good policy maker you have to be)
Really interesting combination of economics, addiction and health policy which will have you thinking outside of the box.
This course was a seminar structured as an overview of different common addictions (i.e. tobacco, alcohol, illicit drugs) and the role economics can play in policies to address the usages.
Yes. Very interesting content.
course content is interesting. liked the readings. sometimes discussion was too pedestrian. would have liked more economic discussion.
